abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the  Lagos Urban Transport
            Project for Nigeria were as follows: outcome was moderately
            satisfactory, risk to development outcome was moderate, Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was satisfactory. Some of the lessons learned
            include: (i) setting up a strong institutional basis for
            coordinated planning and regulation is critical to the
            success of urban transport projects; (ii) the challenges
            facing cities with respect to urban transport and its
            governance are of long duration and not quickly fixed; (iii)
            critical to the success of the project was steady progress
            with the institutional reforms and the establishment of a
            transport fund, which contributed to the positive outcome by
            improving financial sustainability; (iv) World Bank
            supervision teams need flexibility and the ability to adjust
            the project to take advantage of opportunities that may
            arise; and (v) observing the experience of other countries
            or cities where new public transport concepts have worked
            successfully can convince local stakeholders to adopt a new approach.

Urban Participatory Planning m1326675 808,Urban Development m1327371 699,Urban Transport Policy and Planning

26594950.majtheme: Urban development,Financial and private sector development,Human development

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Lagos Urban Transport
            Project for Nigeria were as follows: outcomes were highly
            satisfactory; the risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible; the Bank's performance was highly
            satisfactory; and the Borrower's performance was also
            highly satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: setting
            up a strong institutional basis for coordinated planning and
            regulation is critical to the success of urban transport
            projects. Interactions with the borrower and beneficiaries
            should take place in a context of their choosing. The impact
            of ongoing changes in policy, governance, and institutional
            frameworks in countries like Nigeria should not be
            underestimated. Allow a measure of flexibility in the design
            and set reasonable targets. A good project monitoring system
            is necessary for effective management-close monitoring
            combined with extensive consultations allows for timely
            adjustments. Implementation of Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) is a
            big challenge and requires considerable up front discussions
            and consensus building. Use transportation planning to sort
            out BRT and other alternatives.

repnme.cdata!: Nigeria - Lagos Urban Transport Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The Lagos Urban Transport Project aims
            to improve the Nigerian Govenrment's capacity to manage
            the transport sector in the Lagos Metropolitan Area and to
            enhance the efficiency of the public transport network. The
            Project was approved by the Board of Executive Directors on
            November 21, 2002 for an amount of SDR 75.5 million (US$100
            million equivalent), and the related Agreement was signed on
            June 24, 2003 and became effective on October 30, 2003, with
            a closing date of June 30, 2008. The project got an
            additional financing which was approved on April 10, 2007
            for an amount of SDR 33.6 million (US$50 million equivalent)
            and the related Amended Agreement was signed on October 30,
            2007, with the revised closing date of June 30, 2009. The
            Borrower then requested an extension of the project from
            June 30, 2009 to August 31, 2010 in order to complete the
            implementation of ongoing activities.

Nigeria - Lagos Urban Transport
            Project : restructuring  (Vol. 2) : Data sheet

10427071.majtheme: Urban development,Human development,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - Lagos Urban Transport Project :
            resettlement action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Lagos Urban Transport Project aims
            at improving the transport infrastructure, transport
            patterns, and the flow of traffic in the metropolitan area.
            While little if any land will be acquired under the project,
            some land acquisition will be necessary in the later years
            of implementation, and resettlement of increasing numbers of
            traders, and transporters will be necessary over the life of
            the project. Moreover, many areas within the right-of-way
            have been occupied by market, and itinerant vendors, stall
            holders, private transport providers, and street dwellers.
            Therefore, this resettlement action plan (RAP) is presented
            following the Laws of Nigeria, and Bank requirements on
            involuntary resettlement, to minimize the extent of land
            acquisition, and resettlement, providing compensation to
            displaced people, and allowing a share in project benefits.
            Compensation will be provided to displaced people for land
            or income losses, household or residential plots losses,
            including lost access to properties as a result of the
            project construction. Vendor, or other business fees will
            also be compensated, while a census will be conducted to
            verify the occupancy status of displaced people, as a matter
            of principle, and practical necessity, to avoid
            opportunistic encroachment. Land replacement will be
            stipulated as per the Land Use Act, and local or state
            governments will be responsible for such replacement, and
            associated costs, including transfer costs. Compensation
            will be paid based on the value of assets, be it for
            buildings and structures, crops, or even future rents costs.
            Grievance mechanisms, based on a consultative process, will
            provide opportunities to redress complaints, and, monitoring
            arrangements shall ensure adequate resettlement activities.
